title: Demand for £5,000-Per-Week Rentals Surges in London
text:
The number of super-prime tenants agreeing to pay £5,000 (US$6,147) or more per week soared to a seven-year high in the second quarter of 2019, according to a report from Knight Frank on Monday.



Luxury tenancies have surged as a number of would-be buyers in the U.K. capital wait for more clarity amid ongoing political and economic fracas. The weak sterling has likewise created more demand among foreigners who find their money has more spending power than it did before Britain’s vote to leave the European Union in mid-2016.

In the year through June, there were 153 tenancies agreed to with weekly rent at £5,000 or more—the highest recorded for that time period.



Brexit isn’t the only geopolitical issue on people’s minds, said Tom Smith, head of super-prime lettings at Knight Frank. Affluent renters want to remain flexible as global trade tensions worsen and renewed fears of global economic slowdown.



“People are watching and waiting for the political situation to play out and some have decided to rent,” Mr. Smith said.



Americans and other U.S. dollar-based buyers, in particular, have helped fuel demand for super-prime rentals, as the greenback now has about 20% more spending power against pound sterling than it did in the years before the Brexit referendum.

They’re driving demand in areas like St. John’s Wood, home to the American School in London, and Notting Hill, according to Knight Frank.



Meanwhile, strong demand and a drop-off in new listings have caused the supply of uber-posh rentals to plummet. New super-prime listings fell 26% in the second quarter compared to the same period a year ago, according to the report.
